questions.question: A researcher wants to estimate the average time spent by people on a new app. A sample of 200 users showed an average usage time of 15 minutes with a standard deviation of 3 minutes. What is the 90% confidence interval for the average usage time on the app?

explanations.a: Incorrect. This interval is not calculated correctly.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This interval is not calculated correctly.
explanations.c: Correct! The 90% confidence interval for the average usage time is calculated as 13.9 to 16.1 minutes.
explanations.d: Incorrect. This interval is not calculated correctly.

questions.question: A sample of 150 students was taken, and their average score on a standardized test was 85 with a standard deviation of 10. What is the standard error of the mean for this sample?

explanations.a: Incorrect. The standard error of the mean is calculated differently.
explanations.b: Incorrect. The standard error of the mean is calculated differently.
explanations.c: Correct! The standard error of the mean for this sample is \(0.71\).
explanations.d: Incorrect. The standard error of the mean is calculated differently.

questions.question: A sample of 80 cars showed an average fuel efficiency of 30 miles per gallon with a standard deviation of 3 miles per gallon. What is the margin of error for a 99% confidence interval for the population mean fuel efficiency?

explanations.a: Incorrect. The margin of error is larger for a 99% confidence level.
explanations.b: Correct! The margin of error for a 99% confidence interval is calculated as \(1.2\) miles per gallon.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The margin of error is larger for a 99% confidence level.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The margin of error is larger for a 99% confidence level.

questions.question: You have a sample of 100 observations with a sample mean of 50 and a standard deviation of 10. What is the standard error of the mean?

explanations.a: This answer is incorrect. The standard error of the mean is calculated by dividing the standard deviation by the square root of the sample size. In this case, it would be 10 / sqrt(100) = 1.0.
explanations.b: This answer is incorrect. The standard error of the mean is calculated by dividing the standard deviation by the square root of the sample size. In this case, it would be 10 / sqrt(100) = 1.0.
explanations.c: This answer is incorrect. The standard error of the mean is calculated by dividing the standard deviation by the square root of the sample size. In this case, it would be 10 / sqrt(100) = 1.0.
explanations.d: This answer is correct. The standard error of the mean is calculated by dividing the standard deviation by the square root of the sample size. In this case, it would be 10 / sqrt(100) = 1.0.

questions.question: You have a sample of 50 observations with a sample mean of 75 and a standard deviation of 5. Construct a 95% confidence interval for the population mean.

explanations.a: This answer is incorrect. To construct a 95% confidence interval, you would use the formula: sample mean ± (critical value) * (standard error). The correct confidence interval would be 75 ± 1.96 * (5 / sqrt(50)), which is approximately 72.42 to 77.58.
explanations.b: This answer is incorrect. To construct a 95% confidence interval, you would use the formula: sample mean ± (critical value) * (standard error). The correct confidence interval would be 75 ± 1.96 * (5 / sqrt(50)), which is approximately 72.42 to 77.58.
explanations.c: This answer is incorrect. To construct a 95% confidence interval, you would use the formula: sample mean ± (critical value) * (standard error). The correct confidence interval would be 75 ± 1.96 * (5 / sqrt(50)), which is approximately 72.42 to 77.58.
